body.title: How does XML work?

precis.p: Standardized by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), the Extensible Markup Language (XML) has a rich body of technologies and tools that support it. Though the SPFE architecture could be implemented in other ways, XML was selected because of its robust set of tools and the fact that it is an open standard.

body.p: The Extensible Markup Language (XML) is, as stated by its standardizing body, the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), "a simple text-based format for representing structured information." Because it is an open standard based on a rich history of markup formats and the work of many people, XML is widely used and is supported by a strong set of XML technlogies. The SPFE Open Toolkit is based on XML and its supporting technologies.

section.title: What is XML?
section.p: The essense of the format is that textual information is placed within tagged containers called elements. This page, which was written using XML markup, begins with a snippet of XML like that below.

An element is a content container. An element begins with a tag, an identifying name enclosed in angle brackets, and ends with a matching tag, which preceeds the identifier with a slash. We speak loosely when referring to both opening and closing tags and everything inbetween as an element, but stricktly speaking, the element is just the container. We do take care not to call a tag an element or an element a tag. Think of a tag as a lid.

In the snippet of XML above, <title> is an opening tag and </title> is its closing tag. (We need a lid on both ends.) The title element holds a byline element, which holds an author-name element, which holds an author's name in simple text.

Why the author-name element? It seems redundant; we could have placed the author's name directly in the byline element. But that would have presented a problem if there were more than one author. A simple comma may suffice for you and I to divide the text into a list of multiple authors, but we don't want to that task to a computer program. By placing each author's name in a separate element, we have created unambiguous markup.

A tag associates metadata with its element's contents. A computer program with instructions for the tag can then process the element and its contents properly. In XML, metadata is not only information about contents but is also information that instructs a program what to do. A tag is not just a lid, it's a lid with an instructive label.

With elements containing other elements, among them there must be some that don't contain and some that are not contained. We call the elements within a containing element that element's children and call that element the contained element's parent. Thus, among them all, some are both children and parent, some are children only, and others are parents only.
But a valid XML document can only have one parent. All elements in an XML file must derive from a single root element. We call the root element the document element.

Sometimes a tag needs some additional information to work properly. For example, the HTML <a> tag represents a hyperlink but needs extra information to provide a link address. That information can be given by adding an attribute. In the following, the href attribute is added to the <a> tag.
Whereas elements do the primary work of an XML document, specialist need to be called in for some tasks. Along with elements, you'll often find the following other components in an XML document.

li.p: Comments are for the benefit of human readers. A comment is bracketed in the form <!-- a comment -->.

Processing instructions provide a computer program with instructions that don't pertain to any particular element. A processing instruction has the form <?keyword attributes ?>. You will typically see a processing instruction at the top of an XML file, which alerts a program that it is an XML file: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

section.p: The W3C website provides a wealth of resources for learning more about XML and XML technologies. Liam R. E. Quin's article XML Essentials is a good place to start.

section.title: What is a valid XML document?
section.p: Though tagged elements imply meaning, a computer program can't interpret them properly unless it's coded to do so. Further, a program generally can't process an element correctly unless it comes upon the element in the proper context. For example, how should a program interpret the element <title>A Title</title> placed in the midst of a paragraph, even though it were coded to recognize a title element?

To avoid such ambiguity, an XML document needs to follow certain rules to be valid. These rules, called schemas, define which elements can go where and what they can contain. Thus a valid XML document has a defined structure. The SPFE Open Toolkit uses the XML Schema standardized by W3C. To be processed, every XML file the toolkit uses must be valid.

section.title: What XML document types does the SPFE Open Toolkit use?
section.p: The toolkit works with two kinds of XML documents.

Most of the XML documents you will work with when creating content are, of course, content documents. These all have a common basic structure: a root document element with two children, a head element and a body element. The example below shows the structure for the generic topic XML structure.
section.codeblock: <generic-topic> <head> <!-- Topic header goes here. It contains metadata about the document. --> </head> <body> <title>This is a title</title> <!-- The body goes here. It contains the actual content. --> </body> </generic-topic>

section.title: Who uses XML?
section.p: Many methods can and are used to add metadata to content, but those that use XML to markup documents are the most widespread and robust. These include the following:

li.p: The Darwin Information Typing Architecture (DITA), which has been standardized by the OASIS consortium, defines an XML markup architecture for creating structured content.
DocBook defines an XML markup for books and similarly structured documents. Like DITA, an OASIS technical committee maintains its standard.
